questions.text: Which Incoterm places the maximum obligation on the seller?
questions.explanation: DDP requires the seller to handle all costs and risks, including import duties and taxes, up to the buyer's premises.

questions.text: Which Incoterm places the minimum obligation on the seller?
questions.explanation: EXW means the seller simply makes the goods available at their own premises. The buyer handles everything else.

questions.text: What is the primary function of a Bill of Lading (B/L)?

options.A: It is an invoice for the goods
options.B: It acts as a receipt for cargo, a contract of carriage, and a document of title
options.C: It certifies the origin of the goods

questions.explanation: The B/L is a crucial document serving these three functions in international shipping.

questions.text: Who is responsible for paying import duties and taxes under the DDP term?
questions.explanation: Under DDP (Delivered Duty Paid), the seller bears all risks and costs, including import clearance.

questions.text: In a Letter of Credit (L/C) transaction, who guarantees payment to the seller?
questions.explanation: The Issuing Bank undertakes to pay the beneficiary (seller) provided compliant documents are presented.

questions.text: What is a 'Commercial Invoice' primarily used for?
questions.explanation: Customs authorities use the Commercial Invoice to determine the value of goods for duties and taxes.

questions.text: Which document certifies the country where the goods were manufactured?
questions.explanation: The Certificate of Origin is used to determine tariff rates and trade agreement eligibility.

questions.text: Under the Incoterm FOB (Free on Board), when does risk transfer from seller to buyer?

options.B: When goods are delivered to the buyer's warehouse
options.C: When goods are loaded on board the vessel at the port of shipment
options.D: When goods arrive at the destination port

questions.explanation: Risk transfers when the goods are placed on board the vessel nominated by the buyer at the named port of shipment.

questions.text: What does 'HS Code' stand for?
questions.explanation: The Harmonized System is a standardized numerical method of classifying traded products.

questions.text: A 'Third-Party Logistics Provider' (3PL) typically handles:
questions.explanation: 3PLs provide outsourced logistics services for part or all of a company's supply chain management functions.

questions.text: Which mode of transport is generally the slowest but most cost-effective for large volumes?
questions.explanation: Ocean freight is significantly cheaper per unit for bulk/heavy goods but has the longest transit time.

questions.text: What is 'Demurrage'?

options.B: A charge for detaining a container at the terminal beyond the free time

questions.explanation: Demurrage is charged when a container is left at the port/terminal longer than the allowed free days.

questions.text: What is 'Detention' in shipping?

options.A: When a ship is delayed at sea
options.B: A charge for keeping a container outside the port/terminal beyond the free time

questions.explanation: Detention applies to the time the container is in the customer's possession outside the port.

questions.text: Which organization manages the Incoterms rules?
questions.explanation: The ICC publishes and maintains the Incoterms rules.

questions.text: For air freight, 'Chargeable Weight' is calculated based on:

options.C: The higher of Actual Weight or Volumetric Weight

questions.explanation: Carriers charge based on whichever is greater: the gross weight or the volumetric weight (checks density).

questions.text: What is a 'Packing List' used for?

options.A: To list the price of each item
options.B: To detail the contents, weight, and dimensions of each package

questions.explanation: It helps customs and the receiver verify that the physical cargo matches the documentation.

questions.text: Under CIP (Carriage and Insurance Paid To), the seller must provide insurance cover at what level?
questions.explanation: In Incoterms 2020, CIP requires the seller to obtain insurance complying with Institute Cargo Clauses (A) - All Risks.

questions.text: The 'Importer of Record' (IOR) is responsible for:

options.C: Ensuring imported goods comply with local laws and paying duties

questions.explanation: The IOR is the entity officially responsible for the import process and compliance.

questions.text: Which document is required for hazardous materials (HazMat) shipping?
questions.explanation: An SDS provides information on the properties of hazardous chemicals and how to handle them safely.

questions.text: What is 'Cross-Docking'?

options.A: Storing goods for a long time
options.B: Unloading materials from an incoming truck and loading them directly onto outbound trucks with little to no storage in between

questions.explanation: Cross-docking minimizes warehousing costs by moving goods quickly from receiving to shipping.

questions.text: Which term describes logistics that handles returns, repairs, and recycling?
questions.explanation: Reverse Logistics deals with the flow of goods from the customer back to the seller/manufacturer.

questions.text: A 'Bonded Warehouse' is a facility where:

options.B: Imported goods can be stored without paying duties until they are removed
options.D: Goods are sold to the public

questions.explanation: Bonded warehouses allow deferral of duty payment until goods enter the local market.

questions.text: What does 'TEU' stand for in container shipping?
questions.explanation: TEU is the standard unit for describing a ship's cargo carrying capacity (based on a 20ft container).

questions.text: What is a 'Letter of Indemnity' (LOI) often used for?

options.B: To secure the release of cargo without an original Bill of Lading

questions.explanation: An LOI indemnifies the carrier against claims if they release cargo without the original B/L.

questions.text: The 'Last Mile' in logistics refers to:

options.C: The final step of the delivery process from a distribution center to the end user

questions.explanation: Last Mile delivery is often the most expensive and complex part of the supply chain.
